summary_points.title: Sensex & Nifty Technical Outlook
summary_points.summary: Technically, the Sensex’s 50-day simple moving average (around 81,900) is a key support level, with any dip below potentially dragging the index toward the 20-day SMA near 81,100–81,000 or even 80,700–80,400. Conversely, a sustained breakout above 81,900 could open the way to immediate resistance at 82,500 and further upside toward 83,300, according to Kotak Securities and Share.Market analysts.

summary_points.title: Fed Rate-Cut Optimism After Jackson Hole
summary_points.summary: Jerome Powell’s Jackson Hole speech, which hinted at a possible Federal Reserve rate cut as early as September, lifted market sentiment in India. Traders ramped up bets on monetary easing, with Fed funds futures pricing in nearly a 90% probability of a rate reduction, up from about 75% before his remarks.

summary_points.title: Weekly Rebound Meets End-Week Selloff
summary_points.summary: The Indian market staged a strong comeback last week, with the BSE Sensex gaining 0.88%. However, the benchmarks snapped a six-day winning streak on Friday as panic selling ahead of Powell’s speech saw the Nifty 50 lose 213 points, the Sensex shed 693 points and the Bank Nifty fall 606 points.

summary_points.title: Global Cues Signal Higher Open
summary_points.summary: Asian indices—Japan’s Nikkei 225, South Korea’s Kospi and Hong Kong futures—all traded higher on Monday, while US stock futures rose after Powell’s speech. Gift Nifty was trading at a premium of roughly 55–68 points to domestic Nifty futures, indicating a positive start for Indian benchmarks.

summary_points.title: Sectoral Winners & Losers
summary_points.summary: Auto heavyweights such as M&M, Maruti and Bharat Electronics led gains among the Nifty constituents, while industrial names including Grasim, Asian Paints and Adani Enterprises underperformed, reflecting mixed sectoral flows amid broader volatility.

top_performing_sectors.explanation: IT stocks jumped about 2.5–2.75% on growing expectations of a Fed rate cut after dovish comments from Jerome Powell.
The FMCG index rose 0.91% on hopes of increased consumption amid proposed GST reforms.
Auto heavyweights like M&M and Maruti led gains as robust demand forecasts and company-specific earnings drove the segment higher.

underperforming_sectors.explanation: The Realty index plunged nearly 2% amid broad-based profit-taking and risk-off sentiment ahead of key global cues.
Consumer Durables fell almost 2% as investors sold cyclicals in anticipation of mixed earnings and policy uncertainty.
Oil & Gas stocks dropped close to 2% on concerns over slowing global demand and market jitters around monetary policy.

gainers.reason: Shares rose 2.68%, making it the biggest mover on the upside for the day.
Shares gained 2.32% on expectations of increased consumption amid the proposed GST reforms.
Shares climbed 1.85%, led by strong auto‐sector momentum.

losers.reason: Shares plunged 4.03%, the steepest fall in the Nifty, amid broad‐based market selling.
Shares fell 3.35% as investors booked profits in the pharmaceutical space.
Shares dropped 2.87% amid sharp selling pressure in the metal segment.

market_drivers.summary: Today’s market oscillated in a narrow range as robust domestic liquidity and falling interest rates were offset by profit-booking from foreign institutional investors and muted global cues around trade tariffs and geopolitical uncertainty. Hopes of tax reforms, including potential GST rationalization, and a revival in consumer spending and private investment underpinned sentiment, but a plateau in corporate earnings growth kept participants cautious. In the absence of fresh company-specific triggers, the tug-of-war between strong domestic flows and hesitant foreign demand capped any significant move, leaving benchmarks largely flat.
